headline.print_headline: After Adding Online Privacy Protections, F.T.C. Chief Resigns

docs.abstract: Jon Leibowitz will resign as chairman of the Federal Trade commission, ending four-year tenure in which he pushed for online privacy protections and sought to restrain unfair competition.

docs.abstract: European officials say that Google has submitted proposals aimed at ending a three-year antitrust case focused on its search service, but the offer does not prevent rivals from seeking to prolong its legal problems.

headline.seo: Journalists’ E-Mail Accounts Targeted in Myanmar
headline.main: E-Mails of Reporters in Myanmar Are Hacked
headline.print_headline: E-Mails Of Reporters In Myanmar Are Hacked

docs.abstract: Several journalists who cover Myanmar say that they have received warnings from Google that their e-mail accounts may have been hacked by 'state-sponsored attackers'; some journalists speculate that attempts to hack into e-mail accounts might be linked to conflict in northern Myanmar, where ethnic Kachin rebels are fighting government troops for control over territory near Chinese border.

byline.contributor: Wai Moe contributed reporting from Laiza, Myanmar.

headline.seo: Samsung Armors Android to Take On BlackBerry
headline.main: Samsung Armors Android to Take On BlackBerry

docs.abstract: Samsung Electronics has been quietly adding security enhancements and features to Google Android software that runs on its smartphones to give businesses more secure phone option and to compete with BlackBerry; introduces new software, named Knox, at international cellphone industry trade show in Barcelona, Spain.

byline.contributor: Brian X. Chen reported from Barcelona and Ian Austen from Ottawa.
